First: load all food, and anything else with strong odors (i.e. lip balm, hand lotion, cologne, snacks etc...), in a separate pack, barrel pack, waterproof bag (an over sized re-sealable zip block bag should work perfectly). 

Second: rope it up over an outstretched limb or between two trees with one small metal pulley (found at any hardware store). Throw the pulley rope over the branch, with the other rope being passed through the pulley. Then tie the other end of the pulley rope to a tree and hoisting up the heavy pack with the other rope. The pulley also adds as a good weight on the end of the rope while tossing the rope over a single limb or over the rope. Remember to use a thick strip of fluorescent duck tape to mark your rope so that when you go to retrieve your goods, it will be easy to find.

Tip: Make sure to set up the bear rope early in the evening so you just have to go and pull the food pack up before bed. There's nothing worse than looking for a proper tree to hang your food in when it's pitch dark, other than being mauled to death (unless that is a personal goal for the night).
author: Ty T.

description:
If I could have created my own personal perfect bar, this would be it. From the decor to the staff to the drinks, I was in my happy place. Churchill serves a variety of mules (the Moscow mule was to die for) and the bar tenders are super knowledgeable and even created an amazing drink at my friends and my request. I wish I knew his name because it blew us away but basically we asked for a not-too-sugary tequila drink. It tasted like cucumber goodness with tequila. We all loved it.

I was also SERIOUSLY thrilled about the beer list. Living in San Diego for the past six years, I've been kind of bummed about the beer lists at some of the bars in the Bay Area. But I was pleased to find Green Flash, AleSmith, Saison Dupont, Drake's and even Delirium Tremens on the menu.

The crowd was great as well; friendly folk looking to mingle in a non-creepy way. That plus the drinks made it a night to remember and I can't wait to go back!
author: Allie S.

description: This place is great for a drink after work or a drink. Period. Situated near the castro and a block away from Market street. Its super central. Parking can be iffy. They have a stocked full bar and a barkeeps that really know their stuff. The mojito was superb.
author: Michelle I.

description:
Love the interior design. Their cocktails are great. I tried one with Rosemary syrup, it was sweet and awesome. Then the other one on top of  the cocktail list, I forgot the name, was really strong, made of Jose Cuervo tequila, was pretty good too. 

The crowd was a cool mix of straight and gay. Most ppl are hot!:)
author: Shell J.

description:
Love the mason jars they use for the drinks. LOVE.

Bartender was awesome - I told her to make me something fruity and delicious and she hooked it up. 

Inside sort of reminds me of Rye with the "recycled wood" (can't remember the word) decor and there's a pool table in the back.  Pretty spacious and the loungey seats are facing Market street so creates a cool vibe as well.

Definitely recommending my butt off.
author: Melody T.

description:
Churchill is my new favorite bar!  Originally, my friends and I were going to go to Blackbird. But with a long line to get in, due to a group of friends letting friends cut in front, causing the line to get longer. We decided to leave and head to Churchill.  

On a busy Saturday night, my friends and I scored prime seats at the bar. The bartender, Anthony, welcomed us to the place, as it was our first time.  The bar has an extensive liquor collection lining the wall, that I was like a dear in headlights. Amazed by the beauty of it.

Their cocktail menu is very classy & creative, that I commend the Mixologist.  From the menu I tried the Monte Carlo and the Home front. Both were excellent.  

But the true cocktail of the evening was the one that I asked Anthony to make. I asked him to make a drink that he would drink. After asking the type of preference of the cocktail, he performed his magic. Whiskey, bitters, vermouth, and a herb liquor were all mixed together and out came the best cocktail of the night which we named "The Afterhour".  The taste was smooth,a little sweet, with a fragrant smell.    

Thank you Anthony for your excellent service and mixology magic.  I look forward to my next visit.
author: Marck N.

description: Solid drinks place that offers cocktails, a variety of beer, and a few wines.  Atmosphere was pleasant - not too loud with plenty of high stools and tables.  We came relatively early on a Saturday night while waiting for a table at a nearby restaurant so it wasn't too crowded but I can imagine this place getting crazy later on.  Note that they have billiards in the back near the restrooms.
author: Andrea L.

description:
It was love at first visit when I went in and felt the atmosphere & tried the unbelievable drakes stout which THEY HAVE ON TAP

Waiting to go back, just waiting.
author: Zhenya S.

description:
Love this place. Another Castro bar treasure. The bartenders are super attentive and fast. They have a great beer tap selection and the interior is cozy and comfortable. Couches on one side and tables/hi tables to hang out.
Super mixed crowd. The mixed cocktails are strong and original. My favorite bar in the castro.
author: Annie A.

description: Good place for drinks and watching Giants game.  Service is always good.  Craft cocktails + draft beers + good service.
author: Wendy S.

description:
This place makes me feel oddly patriotic. Mayhaps it is the giant framed American flag on the wall as you head to the bathroom, or maybe it's when I walked in here and the first two guys I see have cowboy hats and leather boots on. Maybe it's all the wood. U-S-A!

This is a fun place to go for happy hour, where they have drink specials and a pretty good selection of beers on tap. I tried one of their cocktails and it was more strong than tasty, which is not a bad dilemma, but it was still pretty good. The vibe is great, relaxed but with a good buzz. There's not an overabundance of places to sit, but if you get some of the nice couches or chairs, you get a very comfortable corner spot from which to people watch. I also loved the open design with the large windows that open out onto the corner of Church and Market. Another design element I liked were the bathrooms. It's always nice to walk into a bathroom where you feel like it wasn't just an afterthought. The pool table in the back seemed like a nice area to hang out. There weren't too many people crowded around it, so I'm not sure what the wait is like. 

Oh yeah, and one of the bartenders was dressed in an air force flightsuit? Not really sure how that blends with the theme. Overall service was pretty quick and friendly. The place gets kind of packed, so be prepared to mill about as you sip on your libations.
author: Saunders C.

description:
I've heard just about every knock on Churchill.

It's too crowded.

It's too douchey.

It's too hipster.

It's too pricey.

It may be all those things but despite the complaints I've enjoyed myself every ten or so times I've come here.  It's been interesting to watch the transition of this corner bar.  It was the Transfer which was pretty scary outside of Frisco Disco nights which were great.  Then it was the BOC (Bar On Church) which seemed to take the worst elements of Vegas and put them in SF.  Churchill feels like a keeper as it's a great bar that is mostly chill and handles just about all of your needs.

Good things about Churchill abound.  Despite the crowds that have been here, the bartenders are able to just plow through the masses without seeming like they're rushing.  I've done everything from getting a drink with a friend to attending a goodbye party and though at first ominous, the space always seems to work out.  The cocktails are solid and as far as the prices go, it really isn't bad, especially when it comes to their beer.  You'd think a place like this would have $7 taps but you can get great local craft stuff for a $5 a glass.  The selection is also impressive, being a mix of random though you can usually count on a good Belgian, a decent IPA, something from Drake's and (in a delightful twist) a sour beer of some ilk is typically available.

I'll always be a dive bar type of guy but if you're inviting, I'm hard pressed to think of reasons not to go here for a drink.
author: Steven R.

description:
Churchill is an excellent spot for happy hour drinks. I love the interior; it reminds me of a ship, with the wood paneling, rope, lanterns and drinks served in jars. There are lots of comfortable seating options if you're there reasonably early or at an off time, but (like any good bar) it can get crowded and loud pretty quickly. 

They have a lot of fun cocktails, but the El Diablo is particularly good -- I highly recommend it if you like tequila.
author: Katie M.

description:
Did you know they have an upstairs called "The Office" that you can rent out for parties? 'Cause I didn't until last week. The space is awesome too! Big enough for a decent sized party.

I had an old fashion that was delicious! They also had out a bowl of punch that was like gin lemonade. I'd have that again.
author: Jeanette L.

description:
Churchill has a space upstairs called The Office that is only available for private rental. There is a private bar upstairs along with bathrooms. The bar minimum is $1500 & he facility fee is $700. The space is perfect for about 50-60 people.

Churchill itself is  down to earth bar with classy cocktails. Their drinks are reasonably priced and seating is aplenty. There's a pool table in the back along with a jukebox. 

Parking: not horrible, not great.
author: Rosa L.

description:
The best part of this place is the fact that they have a beer called Uncle Jesse's Pale Ale.  Have mercy.  What else do you need in a San Francisco bar?

Churchill is pretty cool place.  There's a great, large bar on the back wall with pretty bottles all in a row.  I thought it was divey, when I walked in, but then I went into the bathroom - it's beautiful!  

I unfortunately didn't drink enough to NOT remember the night like Johnny T.  So I'll have to come back again.  Check it!  You can play hipster and look like you don't care without having to go to an actual dive!
author: Heidi P.

description:
My friends and I used to come to this location while it was still Bar on Church, which was basically only good because it had super cheap PBR on certain nights and relatively cheap drinks in general. Overall, Bar on Church was a pretty dingy/gross bar.

On the total flip side, Churchill is awesome. The decor is very original and classy (lots of wood paneling, old-fashioned look) and the bar is clean. I went in during happy hour ($1 off all drinks) on a Saturday afternoon and got a nice pint of IPA in a mason jar for $4. The mixed drinks were $9 ($8 during happy hour) and looked interesting and delicious, though I didn't get a chance to try any.

There are very comfy/clean couches and decent sized wooden tables, all of which are very conducive to good chatting. Also, the pool table has been moved to a much more functional location near the bathrooms which have also been significantly upgraded and are now nice and clean.

Too long, didn't read: Good prices, great ambiance, great place to have a drink and chat with friends.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Prohibition style drinks, dive bar uniform/attitude, hipster drinkware, mixologist knowledge, industrial feel.

I saw Aviation gin on the shelf, and asked how much it was. Bartender asked if I wanted an Aviation cocktail or the gin. Nice. Not everyone knows there is a cocktail also, +1. 

There's also a huge american flag mounted on the wall, and a nice pool table in the back. 

Despite being in the Castro, this place is a total meat market. Which could be nice. However, I saw few couples sucking face. Yeah. I saw you. Quit with the innuendo with pool cues and slowly mouthing your drinks. Get a room already.
author: Ben T.

description: Decent beer choices. Usually packed. They are SUPER into their $20 card minimum so... Be prepared to be forced into getting hammered in order to make things easier for them. LAME.
author: Molly M.

description:
I have a well documented stance on lines at bars. Strictly bars, not Vegas/South Beach clubs, but bars. Long story short, not a fan. I'm going to spend money. Chances are I'm dressed well. Chances are I'm going in with at least one lovely lady. And given that I'm just going to a bar, chances are I'm not that picky about which one I go to.

So when I arrived at a not-so-crowded Churchill's early (before 10) one Friday evening only to wait outside for 20 minutes, suffice it to say I wasn't in happyland. Thankfully, once I did get inside I quickly realized that this place is pretty legit.

Inventive cocktails, a killer whiskey selection, an upscale southern vibe with a killer decor, especially when stacked against the dive bars typical to the area, and FINALLY a place that isn't cash only. These are all reasons I was able to shake off the bad vibes and enjoy myself...a lot, since these guys pour with a heavy hand. 

The group we met arrived by 9 and had no trouble getting in, so note to self: get there early next time. And yes, I'm sure there'll be a next time.
author: Alex H.

description: This is a pretty cool place to grab a drink and catch up with friends. I didn't stay long enough to check out the scene but the bartenders here make great drinks. I highly recommend the Homefront. It is served in a mason jar which is pretty chic.
author: Tim G.

description:
02.04.12 || bookmarked 06.06.11

No tooty fruity here.  Excellent drinks, awesome bar staff, amazing bouncer (that's right, kicked people out of our reserved corner couch upon arrival).

Love drinks served in mason jars.  Maybe for the quantity?

For a low key and a hell of a time with great friends, stop in Churchill for a drink (or a few).
author: Jenny L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this bar for over a year now. I finally was heading toward the Mission and was able to stop in for a drink or two. They have a great drink menu and the bartenders are all super nice. They serve the drinks in ball mason jars (which being born in Indiana is great). We only had two beers and then had to move on, but I'm looking forward to being able to come back here again. 

They also have some fantastic marinated peanuts that are sweet and salty and delicious. The perfect addition to any drinking experience.
author: Lauren D.

description: My favorite bar in the city. The cocktails are great, atmosphere looks like a post WWII watering hole, and the Bloody Marys are bloody good on a Sunday afternoon. A++ will drink here again.
author: John L.

description:
Three straight nights. Three new bars.

Round one: Churchill

Opening: Greeted by a very generous stranger at the bar who insisted on buying us a shot of whiskey. Make that very generous friend.

Follow-up: Continued the whiskey story with a stiff Old Fashioned. Perfect for sipping. Perfect for conversation.

Scene: Polished beverage oasis in a land of debauchery.

Barkeep: Confident. No doubt would have made anything requested.

Tip: Grab a seat on one of the couches by the window. Not crowded on July 4th. Bet you have to fight for them otherwise

Investment: High. Twenty plus for the pair including tip.

Last call: Worth it. Quality favored over quantity.

Another round: Tradition (http://goo.gl/TeYbk) and Iron & Gold (http://goo.gl/RYZlJ)
author: Jason B.

description:
A chic dive bar that's good for any occasion. 

There is a plethora of bars the Mission/Castro, but this is my go-to neighborhood bar to meet a friend or start the night with visiting friends.  The mixed drinks and beer selection is good, design and decor is comforting, and great for people watching along Market Street.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Classy?! In the Castro?! Oh my.

Totally digging this bar on a Friday night. The last time I was in San Francisco was in May and Churchill opened one month later. I used to frequent this joint when it was the Bar on Church. So many hilarious and fun memories on Ladies Night. RIP BOC. Now this bar is VERY handsome indeed. 

+ Fully stocked bar.
+ Whiskey, whiskey, whiskey.
+ Strong mixed drinks.
+ Drinks served in mason jars.
+ Mixed crowd.
+ Gorgeous/cozy interior decoration.
+ Good balance of sitting/standing space.
author: Ileana H.

description:
Very cool vibe!

Started out upstairs for a private party in The Office...which was awesome and then when that ended we all headed downstairs to Churchill.

You can go from a great Old Fashion to a cheap $2 Olympia without skipping a beat. Beware, it gets LOUD in there, but I guess that's part of fun and creates a upbeat atmosphere.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Like some of the other reviewers, I was glad to see the BOC go, which created kind of a slog to try to walk through this piece of sidewalk on my way home from work. But I also used to meet friends for happy hour at the bar at Home, and had been feeling that gap since Home's demise. So, I was curious about Churchill. 

Churchill is a great place to meet friends after work -- predictable atmosphere, background music conducive to conversations, and a few cute dogs in attendance. The drinks are good and the place is clean (so far). 

The clientele is kind of homogeneously young and white and affluent due to the ongoing gentrification of our neighborhood, but since the kids generally have to work late at their dot-com and advertising jobs, humorless feminists, nonprofit workers, and old-school leftists can hang out for an hour or two after work without catching too many hipster cooties.
author: Laurie N.

description:
This is a pretty hard review to write. It's not because I don't know what to say about the place. It's because I am pretty sure I temporarily lost use of one or more of my senses here and I am only sure that the rest of the evening happened because a.) I am here writing you today and b.) I had photographic evidence I was still on planet Earth and hadn't been shunted to a parallel dimension.

Granted, I was rocking a pretty serious Olsen twin diet of polluted air and ennui, but got damn! What do they put in the drinks here? Typically, I eschew bars that serve drinks in mason jars. I get it. It's trendy/kitschy/cool. Whatever. I've been drinking tea/milk/Hi-C out of mason jars since I can remember. It's how we do in the sorta dirrty. I got over my rule and myself when I realized that Churchill had a serious cocktail rep. I got through about half the menu (that I remember) when, in my attempt to tell my friends I was going to the men's (cuz I am not a little boy) room, I couldn't speak to tell them I was leaving, I couldn't move my legs to get me to the restroom, I couldn't see through the crowd to navigate where I was going... I wondered if, in an effort to trend set, I'd imbibed some sort of poison from a South American scorpion (off-menu, of course) and I was slowly being turned to stone. The upside was that I wouldn't pee myself. At least, I don't think stones can pee. As I resigned myself to my rocky fate, I suddenly became ambulatory... but speech still eluded me.

That was probably a good thing, as my buddy told me that I hit on the bartender with some choice bon mots. Since I would like to have a date some time this decade, I'll spare you what (I'm told) I told her. Evidently, I went from game (getting a free beer and smile) to shame (leaving solo and lower lip sticking out in a visible pout).

I don't know what the #*^*( they put in those drinks.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Great bar, much better than the two before it!!

Nice, and nice to look at bartenders make great drinks.  The place is a decent size so it's not as cramped as some other bars in the area.  They also have an excellent liquor selection.
author: Laura P.

description:
Whatever wave of cocktail culture we're on now (anti-vodka, coupe-shaped cocktail glasses, traditional cocktails with modern twists like house-made ingredients, etc.) has probably matured in San Francisco.  There are enough bars to get well-crafted drinks like these that at least one has closed.

Churchill's cocktails are on point, both those on and off their menu.  Though some of them tend to be a little on the sugary side.  I also wouldn't ask for something bespoke when it's busy.  There's also a well-curated rotation of 10 beers on tap.

I'm not sure what the connection is between cocktails and World War II, but the Churchill looks a little like a WWII bunker, albeit a nice one with windows and lit by Edison bulbs.

I did enjoy Churchill.  I wouldn't return on a busy night like Friday or Saturday since it got crowded (with vocal-fryers) to the point that it still took a long time for the efficient bar staff to take orders, make cocktails and settle tabs.
author: Suo L.

description: Don't know how my friend rented the upstairs for her birthday, but it was a great spot, with really nice bartenders, who mixed a mean drink. Melikes cucumber gimlets.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I was very disappointed in Churchill. I came in with three girl friends during happy hour around 4:45. The only other patrons were sitting at the bar. We walked up and it took a while for the bartender to approach us. Kind of annoying since there weren't many people there. 

I ended up ordering the piña colada off their menu and I basically paid for ice with a splash of cocktail. Pathetic. And it's not necessary to serve a piña colada in a Hawaiian fashion in a fancy glass with an umbrella. A mason jar with a slice of pineapple would have sufficed. 

Thanks but no thanks, Churchill.
author: Kate J.

description:
It could be that I'm a bit of a waif, but after the strenuous move of an iron clad bar stool and the mammoth lifting of the drink menu, I think it's safe to say that Churchill might just be reclaimed pieces from... what? A submarine? War remnants from Winston Churchill's era? A lighthouse's grave? Whatever the case, the look and feel are nautically rich, dense, and deep. 

But that's only part of the point of a lounge which features a selective selection of cocktails. My poison - the Bees Knees. Gin, honey, lemon et al, it was a refreshing beverage, paired well with our challenge: having a conversation over the noise level that continued to rise. I think we nabbed the last table in the space. Nevertheless, a stellar spot to unwind, decently priced cocktails and an atmosphere that on another night, I might just have been tempted to strike up conversation with others at the bar. 

5/30: 30 Day Challenge
author: Crystal H.

description: Super solid bartenders.  Decent cocktails, interesting variety of taps.  Great people watching.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Neighborhood Bar Must Haves:

-Comfy couches.

-Solid menu. Bring your friends: the beer snob, the bourbon fan, and the indecisive one that needs a suggestion from the barkeep.

-No 'tude vibe.

-Good tunes.

Bonuses:

-Pool Table.

-Huge windows = Loads of fresh air.

-Ropes on the ceiling.

Things we could do without:

-Queue at the door most nights.
      Tip: Sunday afternoon or early in the week are winners

-The awkward step near the couches / two-level floor that you trip off of sober.

Need to know more:

-You have the address. Now go enjoy yourself.
author: Alissa A.

description:
I am so glad I live near this bar.

I love Bloodhound, so when I heard this bar by the same people I knew I had to try it out. I was not disappointed. The vibe is very cool, lots of great seats at the bar and on couches around the space. We brought a big group and everyone was able to settle in and get comfortable.

The drinks were fantastic. They have awesome beer choices and all the cocktails were artfully prepared - as expected.

In short, this place is awesome. Check it out!
author: Gretchen S.

description:
Friendly and attentive bartenders and a little bit of history to this place.

Heard it was based on a WWII theme, I liked how there was a huge old American flag on the wall.

Met some pretty cool people here and had some good beer.

The right bars have always been a great place to gather and be social since time immemorial. May these bars find people in good times and good health. =)

Can get packed, but nice place to stand and talk with the dim lights, the music is a little too loud though but it works for them, makes people get closer to allow for more room for more customers.
author: Thanh T.

description:
One day, I will be here at 4 pm on a weekday or 2 pm on a weekend, and get to sit in one of the front booths. Seriously, what some prime seating that is always super crowded and I think those lucky individuals never leave that spot. 

I love Churchill; just like their sister place Bloodhound, the design is pretty cool and the drinks are worth every penny. I think the specialties at Bloodhound are a bit better, but the beer selection at Churchill is pretty vast. BOC was so beat, so Churchill is a refreshing, good change. The place also gets another star for not serving that rancid patron tequila. YUCK.
author: Laura H.

description: Great location, good drink, nice atmosphere.When all others bars are empty, Churchill is always full. I like this place!
author: Merve A.

description: Hey! They remodeled this place, it's a new bar, I didn't know that! This is far from the old dive it used to be! I love the open feel and comfy couches. Great feel to the place and drinks looked good. It was my sober night was just hanging with friends, but the drinks looked yummy. I will be back!
author: Karen T.

description:
nice bar with a good amount of seating. there's also a pool table. 
went on a night where they were short staffed so there was only the one bartender hustling but he stayed very friendly
tried the homefront, swanky panky, and a green flash. the two cocktails were really good. not a huge fan of the green flash
author: Liz V.

description:
I really wish I had the ability to squish people with my thumb and forefinger until they turned into dust. I would do that to pretty much every patron of this bar; the women mostly smell like baby gurl vanilla lavender body spray and Twizzlers while the men all look the same (read: not very good dressers).

The fact that the bar flies are so blah doesn't take away from how cool this bar is though. I'm a fan of the bunker chic design and the mad delicious house cocktails that all run nine bucks. The bartenders seem relaxed despite the crowds. Maybe downing a few more of their cocktails would have helped me ease up too? I've only been in during the weekend rush hours, and while I probably won't be doing that again, I definitely plan on coming back during the weekdays.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Churchill is the new bar by the Bloodhound/Double Dutch people, and like most new bars needs to grow up fast! 

It's also a bar I was so nervous about reviewing I decided I had to go twice before I mentioned it on Yelp! 

I got a strongly worded email from Dylan O'Brien after my review of Bloodhound's decor so I'm treading lightly.... :-/ And the decor at Churchill is pretty successful. I generally like it. There's no sign of 'flee market' anywhere you look, and a wizard bong would be totally out of place. 

I'm not into those ropes, but the whole bar is a solid example of the design theme that's becoming ubiquitous in modern San Francisco...where I guess the goal is to be somewhere between the Gold Rush and a SOMA loft...not so steampunk as to actually be steampunk but definitely steampunk friendly...

There is a nice pool table that takes dollar bills! Respect. But the table is not in the best spot. It's so close to the east wall you practically can't shoot from that side (on opening day they had no short sticks), and an awkward end table of sorts at the southwest corner of the table makes shooting from there difficult but not impossible... 

So what is REALLY wrong with it? So far the drinks seem to suck and I hate the bar set up. 

This group of bar builders seems really into dispensing with the transactional nature of drinking. That's the most favorable interpretation I can give to lining every inch of the bar in stools and abandoning the little black mat you line up at. 

Yeah...turns out standing awkwardly behind sitting, conversing people...not knowing when if ever you'll be served...yelling your order over other people's heads...stretching your arm through their conversation to pay and collect your drink....none of these things make for a better drinking experience. Black mats and lines, please!  

And I've had three of their menu drinks. So I think I'm up on it.  

The Churchill 75 is named after the bar. I feel invited to judge them on it, but that should not be how they want to be judged. It's drinkable but completely forgettable. I actually remember my first ever French 75 because it was surprising, complicated and also ingeniously simple.  The Churchill 75 is none of those things.  

Other drinks: 

The Dos Agaves Margarita is drinkable, but it's not an improvement on the margarita so it should be cut.  I don't think mezcal is a great margarita liquor.  And while it's novel to make a margarita with tequila AND mezcal, if I taste it and it's not a good idea the novelty isn't valuable. It's annoying. 

And the Home Front is actually DISGUSTING! The best description I can give it is rancidly alcoholic chicken soup, and if that sounds remotely good to you then don't take bar advice from me.

On the optimistic side. Blackbird's first drink menu totally sucked too and look at what they are doing now.  I'd really like to give this place 5 stars a year from now, and if they fix their bar setup and their cocktail menu gets as good as their beer menu that's all very possible.
author: Luke M.

description:
Joe Stalin, FDR and Churchill walk into a bar. I'm not sure of the punchline here, but I'd be happy to discuss it with you at this new military-bedecked bar, a milibar if you will.

The setup is probably more Patton (by way of George C. Scott), when you take in the vintage lamps, heavy duty nautical rope (look up) and semi-camo walls that help make up their bar zone. There's a certain ruggedness going, but with enough polish to make this bunker chic.

When it gets crowded, it functions like a typical cantina, or perhaps a raucous mess hall; I'm not sure if I was expecting the staff in uniform -- although there was one bartendress in a hummer of an army midriff! -- but after a few rank and file cocktails, well you can start see why Hitler never stood a chance.

Favorite Churchill Quote: "You have enemies? Good. That means you've stood up for something, sometime in your life."

Fun Churchill Trivia (to share at the bar):
He was born in a cloak room
He did a damn good gorilla imitation
When traveling abroad during World War II, he used the alias "Colonel Walden" for security reasons.
author: Nish N.

description:
Winston Churchill once said, "Everyone has his day and some days last longer than others." I hope the owners of Churchill adopt this as their slogan because this is a bar I'd love to sit near a window and sip whiskey after a long, exhausting jaunt at the office (/street corner).

While comprable to Blackbird, this place feels a little more spacious and their overall decor is a little more cohesive. With old wooden panels and ropes taking the place of a ceiling, with high tables and couches and leather chairs surrounding a circular table, you know every detail was considered in the construction of this establishment. If nothing else, it's a beautiful space. 

They have a great selection of liquors and about 9 beers on tap (along with some that come in the bottle variety). I should have ordered a fancy cocktail, but I began the night drinking Anchor Steam so I wasn't about to ruin my streak.

Love (!) that they served beers in mason jars. It's not a new concept, but it felt refreshing to hold one at a bar.

Churchill simultaneously manages to provide a calm, cool and collected vibe while also being somewhere you can chat loudly with a group of friends and "dance on your own" to the hipster music playing in the background. 

Don't think I didn't hear you last night, Florence & The Machine. Thanks to Churchill, the dog days are over for bars on this cursed corner. We finally have something that should last awhile.
author: Jared S.

description:
Don't get me wrong... I'm a huge fan of dive bars, but in this case I would consider that an insult to classify Churchill as a dive bar.

My first visit was on a Friday night when I was sitting at home feeling sorry for myself in my cute outfit.  I was supposed to be at the Ray LaMontagne concert, but my boyfriend and I had a tiff.  As we all know... there's nothing worse than sitting at home in your cute outfit with nowhere to be!  In comes the rescue brigade (aka amazing girlfriends) and off we went to Churchill.

The ambiance has a rustic nautical appeal that immediately feels inviting and beckons you to stay. The drink menu seals the deal.  I tried the Bee's Knees, Churchill's Southside, and the Homefront.  All really yummy and served in fun but appropriate glassware.

Great crowd, didn't really notice any creepers... well, except for my second visit where this guy literally followed me and my friends in from outside finally forcing me to be blunt and say, "I'm sorry, I have a boyfriend and we are REALLY not interested!"

Will be stopping by again!
author: Regina B.

description: Not sure what all the stars are about. Got there after work on a Friday.  It was really loud and not comfortable.  The stools were steal and hard as a rock, not a comfy seat.. Moved to a table and still couldn't carry a conversation.  The house wine was that just white wine.  IT was dirty and didn't' have a good vibe.  Others seem to be having a good time, i took it they were regulars. Seems the tables needed to be wiped down and the floor swept.  Its a dog friendly bar, so lots of dogs on the couch .  I won't be going back.  If you need a place to drink that allows dogs that's the place or stay home with a beer and your couch.
author: Susie S.

description:
me "Can I get a ***** beer"
cocky bartender "it's out"
me: "what do you have like it"
Cocky bartender "that beer is it's own.  Nothing is like it"
me: rolls eyes..."really?  NOTHING is like it?"  Learn your beers douchebag...
author: Matt V.

description:
I can't even pretend to miss the sticky, dark bars that preceded the Churchill on this corner.

Granted, this place gets much more crowded on a weekend night, but most nights it is a chill place to hang out on a comfy couch and have a conversation over well made cocktails. The bar is sometimes understaffed for the amount of time they have to spend on each drink, but then I just order a bottle of cider and the problem is solved.
author: saru k.

description: Very solid bar. Plenty of room, good drinks, and a casual atmosphere. Have never had a bad time there.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
Ambiance - amazing!
Drinks - great!  (Very Strong)
Crowd - depends.

Overall I have enjoyed Churchill.  The drinks are good, but the crowd can be sketchy (not in a bad sense though.  You get the typical hipsters.  You also get some of the gays (all types).  What I also find is that there are the "others" that think it's a gay bar.  They are there to "ease into the Castro" and act cool.

Listen...I applaud Churchill (and it's sister bars) for continuing with the new and interesting landscape of bars in the city.   We don't need segregation in are bars (gay/str8).  We just need good bars.
author: Eric S.

description:
After so much hype when this place first opened, I finally made it here on my latest SF Homecoming visit in May (after sadly moving away Nov 2011 - my heart still breaks for NorCal, on pretty much a daily basis - anyhow, back to the review), and honestly, we were unimpressed. 

First of all, the doorman hit on me in a surprisingly obvious way (given this was San Francisco, after all, and we were in the Upper Market / Churchill / almost Castro area - i.e. not the Marina). Don't get me wrong - he was totally good looking, and I'm sure had a delightful personality when he wasn't "playing the field," but it was so not-SF, so overt, and while I was in the loo, he even said to my girlfriend "hook me up with your friend." To quote Alicia Silverstone, "As If!". I have a boyfriend, thanks.

Then there was the obnoxiously loud and unescapable music that accompanied the "Bro" scene. OK, so maybe this place is played out. Maybe the time to come here was when it first opened, and now it's lost it's cool. That's highly possible.

As to the drinks - super strong. Of course, it's my fault b/c I ordered a cocktail with Bitters. Oops. My bad. But if I did want such a cocktail, may I recommend 83 Proof instead. Far superior ambiance and crowd. Also, way more friendly bartenders.

The only thing positive I can say is that the decor was stellar. And the loos were HUGE! Especially this part of town. Also they were decorated (!!!) and clean (!!!).
author: Sally M.

description:
I had friends visiting from out of town on Saturday, and was a little stumped as to where I should take them after dinner.  Luckily a friend had a birthday thing at Churchill, because in retrospect, what better way is there to show them the spirit of San Francisco than taking them to Churchill?

It...

1) Is new - "OMG it's a new something! I MUST TRY IT BEFORE EVERYONE ELSE" ~ SFer
2) Had a line out the door - The only thing San Franciscans love more than actually trying hot new places is waiting in line for these new bars/ice cream shops/public restrooms.
3) Had a mixed crowd - We love diversity!  The guy behind me in line called this bar a "bizarro Blackbird", because it is "as gay as Blackbird is straight".  Take that how you will.
4) Has drinks? - Let's face it, we just love alcohol.  This place has drinks, GOOD drinks.  My sidecar was delicioussss.

All in all a pretty awesome bar that I would come back to.  Much better than the jank BOC that it used to be, anyway.
author: jon y.

description: Recently went to this bar and wasn't treated so nicely. My friend claims it's because we were Asians but yet, we knew how to order drinks than the white people there that night!
author: Anni Y.

description:
Finally!  Something in this space that isn't completely sad.  This is the every day man's Blackbird, and I mean that as a compliment.

The interior:  Super cute, but not over-thought.  Thoughtfully designed for a casual cocktail experience with friends.
The drinks:  We sat at the bar and it was one wave of interesting smell after another.  Their drinks are great.  Even the beers on tap are unusual and interesting.
The Crowd:  Mixed, casual, fun!  It was a Wednesday happy hour and the place was busy with a very diverse group of people

I was very impressed.  Casual sophistication and great drinks!
author: Daniel H.

description:
Came here for a birthday gathering for Jane S. and was not disappointed! Great bar, plenty of stools for seating and skilled fast bartenders. It was a Saturday night and even though the place was busy and loud, I still managed to carry on decent conversations with the people around me. 

Drinks are not too expensive, ~$5 for beers and ~$3 for shots, not sure about the cocktails. This place just opened, so everything is new and shiny and lots of space to mill around. There was more space in the back that I didn't get a chance to check out. 

The place is also in a pretty active neighborhood, so didn't have to worry about heading home foreveralone down a sketchy/shady street.
author: Connie C.

description: This place is hardly a dive bar..I love the rustic/masculine decor..and of course..the cool bartenders. A new fav for me...
author: Mimi T.

description:
This place is really starting to come into its own and is worthy of a fourth star.  It stays pretty busy, but without ridiculous lines out the door.  The crowd continues to be mixed, whereas neighboring Blackbird -- although it has never promoted itself as such -- has basically become a gay bar (albeit one that serves actual cocktails).

As with any bar, you have to know who to order from.  And as sad as it was when Trevor E. moved on, they at least have sense enough to keep one top-notch barkeep on duty even on the busiest nights (when admittedly, most of the clientele is ordering shots of Jameson for the boys and vodka sodas for the girls).

Here's a tip: if you're ordering from someone like Jon or Carly (John or Carley?), just ask them "make me something like a...." and fill in your usual drink.  Chances are you'll get something better than what you were going to ask for. 

And if you like this place, check out Bloodhound!  Also a fan.
author: Sven E.

description:
Cool bar, nice rustic/ woody/ industrial decoration.

Drinks a bit expensive, but don't disappoint. 

They occasionally keep a short line outside in order to keep it from becoming a marina style sweaty bumpfest. 

Nice selection of beers on tap.
author: Bruce P.

description:
I live around the corner from here and have been wanting to try this place out.

- Allows dogs, as long as they are calm
- Reasonably priced beers, $9 cocktails
- The place is big but there doesn't seem to be enough sitting area, a lot of the seating is for larger parties, so as long as you don't mind sharing a table with some strangers.
- Pool table in the back

I ended up getting the Bees Knees (Gin, Lemon, Honey and some Lavender syrup) was really good.  I also had another cocktail but I don't remember what it was called but it was like a ginny lemonade.  Very good.

Highly suggest.  Foursquare claims its a dive bar, but it definitely is not a dive bar.

Apparently its supposed to be a WWII themed bar, but nothing in the place screamed world war II except for the American flag with the 48 stars.  The decor was more modern chic rather than retro 1940s-50s.

Not really a gay bar, not really a dive bar.  More of a trendy hipster bar.  Drinks served in mason jars.

-1 star for no food!  Gotta have food or snacks at least to soak in all the alcohol!

Highly suggest!
author: Kameron K.

description: I don't know if it's true but I feel like i'm getting cheated out of beer in their mason jars. they just seem smaller than pint glasses. I'm probably wrong. Anywyas for a bar that looks like it's going for that awesome beer vibe, they don't have that many awesome beers.
author: Misha T.

description: Went in on a Sunday night and it was the least crowded I've ever seen this bar. Despite the fact that there weren't many customers, the service was honestly horrendous. My friend and I stood at the counter waiting to order for at least 10 minutes because the bartender was too busy flirting with someone. The other bartender was rude, too. I'd understand it taking this long if it was super crowded, but it was desolate. The bouncer was nice, though. The drinks are expensive, tiny and the service is way below average.
author: John L.

description: I had no idea this last Wed 6/1 was opening day. I had assumed that it had been open a week or so. Explains the mad crowd. However after 11pm it started to die down a bit. Even with the crowd it wasn't hard to get a drink or four and we hung out near the bar the whole time. The Churchill twist on the Manhattan shifting to another borough, the Brooklyn was excellent. I was also told the Bees Knees was also fantastic. The bartenders know how to mix their cocktails. The space is beautiful and the war era theme works well. I love how the space is broken up into various sections. Lounge, bar, pool table. Rope ceiling and a very well stocked shelf of prime liquor. Great opening. 4.5 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
I stopped by Churchill last pm for a nitecap as I hadn't been before. 

Ok, I understand new means need to get the kinks out but waiting 15 minutes for a drink on a not-so-crowded pm is lame. The bartenders were so busy schmoozing they ignored me, my friend and the couple down from us (who left). And when we finally had our mixed drinks, they tasted weak and not the right proportions to be tasty (ever hear of the straw taste test barkeeps?).

one star each for : straight & gay friendly spot
one star : nice decor
minus two stars for : attitude & bad mixed drinks
author: Missy D.

description:
I've been here a few times now since it's just around the corner and must say it's probably one of my top 3 favorite bars in the area.  First of all it has a great location - especially if you want to have dinner in the Castro/Mission and grab a drink after or meet up with friends after work on a Friday.  

As other reviewers mention, it does get crowded and loud.  Not in a totally obnoxious way if you're okay with loud bars  - people are polite and you can usually eventually get a seat at one of the tables or couch areas.  But it is not exactly the best place to have an intimate conversation on a weekend night.  

The drinks are GREAT. I will reluctantly admit that I think I tried about 5 of them the first time I was there and have since at least tasted most of the other custom cocktails on the menu.  You really cannot go wrong.... I will recommend to NOT get the margarita - don't get me wrong, it's good but there are so many other delicious things on the menu.... try something else first! The bartenders are really friendly and willing to talk to you about the drinks they're making - good people to chat with while you're waiting. (NOTE: $20 minimum on credit cards!)

Also, I LOVE the Castro (hence I live in the neighborhood) but I'll just put it out there that this is not a bar full of gay guys like some of the other bars on the street.  This is actually a pretty mixed crowd given the neighborhood.  I think I really like the fact that it's a diverse group of people there and it makes for good conversations.  

Long story short - go to Churchill! Great SF bar.
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
Churchill is the new bar where the Bar on Church used to be. I never went to BoC but my friends tell me it was pretty good, and they also told me Churchill is a worthy replacement. I agree!

Cocktails here are delicious and complex -- I think there are some on the menu with at least seven or eight ingredients. Very tasty, but the downside is that they take quite a while to make. If it's busy, expect to wait at least ten minutes for your drink. This would probably get better if they'd hire one more bartender. Expect to pay about $10 per drink, less if you're having beer or wine (but then, why would you be at a specialty cocktail bar?).

No food, but they seem okay with people bringing in pizza from across the street.

I've brought my dog in here without problems, too, which is a plus.

And now the downside: this place gets Crowded. Maybe this is because it's still new and exciting, but don't expect to get a seat if you show up past 7 or so on just about any night. With crowds come noise, and Churchill is unfortunately one of the worst offenders here. There are absolutely no soft surfaces in the room; it's all concrete and wood, so noise is just going to reverberate. If you come with a group, make sure everyone's friends with everyone, as you won't be able to hear anyone not sitting or standing right next to you.

All in all, a good place to start your night out with a tasty hand-crafted cocktail. Just don't stay too long, or you'll talk yourself hoarse!
author: Sam K.

description:
Dig the polished design, mixed crowd and chill vibe. The cocktail menu will give you a workout (literally) and there is a great selection of local beers. Prices are fair for the pretty environs - the wide windows and sexy lighting make everyone look a little extra fabulous.

I'm not really a regular anywhere but could envision becoming one here. Also: the ropes! Love them! Kind of make you sway....though that may have been the cocktails.
author: Priya S.

description: Nice local bar.  Even though it says "Dive Bars" on the listing, it's really not.  It's a clean hip bar.  Lots of room to stand or sit.  Attentive bartenders.  Pool table in the back.  Crowd is a mostly hipsters - gay and straight.  My only complaint is that lots of hard surfaces means it gets really loud when it fills up.  Really really loud.  Like shouting to the person sitting right next to you and even then having them respond "what?  what?".
author: Jean K.

description:
First impressions are incredibly important!  And I'm certainly impressed.  For a location to go from a dive bar to a bad dance bar to this is definitely a much needed change here in the Castro.  (By the way, the category of "dive bar" does NOT apply to this venue, so let's try to get it removed from the Yelp profile!)

Upon entering, you're welcomed by the comfortable feel of a friendly neighborhood bar.  The interior has been completely transformed.  The incorporation of natural wood in the decor makes this place feel warm and inviting.  The rope detail above the bar adds a nice touch to the aesthetic.  

But for the important stuff...I was there for only about an hour, as I had to run off to dinner reservations.  It seems that whiskey is a big focus here and though I'm not a whiskey drinker, I can certainly appreciate the vast selection they offer.  Their menu has some specialty drinks that I would have tried had I not been rushed off to a dinner reservation.  In addition, they have a nice beer selection.  

I opted to play it safe due to pending dinner reservations and had a vodka tonic.  Their well vodka is Smirnoff.  Not bad!  The bartender was expedient and pleasant.  So much so that my partner and I had 2 drinks each with plenty of time to drink them in 45 minutes.  Even though there were a good number of people there, I didn't feel cramped or pushed around.  There's plenty of room for everyone!  

Highly recommend this place.  This may very well be my new "After the Theater" night cap destination since my usual spot is no longer an option.
author: Selena F.

description:
I don't necessarily know that I would call Churchill a 'divebar' but you best believe I'll be diving in here more frequently whilst on my bike trips from my place to my lover's.  

My palms always get clammy just before the thin wheels of my bicycle tires thumps on the tracks of Church and Market.  I wonder if this is going to be the time I really eat shit.  No need to worry.  I'll just pop into Churchills and have a strong pour of Bulleit Rye on the rocks.  That ought to steady my grip and send me home--or in my lover's arms in calmer and spicier mood.

This corner, I will admit, really scares me.  With so much going on, I really avoid it at all cost.  But this is the perfect antidote to every Upper Castro, Mission, Lower Haight, Deboce triangle and Nob Hill--dweller.  

Bonus* Interesting, woody warm decor, and lovely rest-rooms.  Always a plus!
author: Mennlay A.

description: Churchill is my go to bar for a low key evening with awesome cocktails and great ambiance. Their old fashioned is the best in town and they have a pool table in the back which is usually open on weeknights.
author: Parag M.

description:
Welp, this is the new Bar on Church, i guess. 3/4 of the same owners from Bloodhound down in SOMA, and the decor all but gives that away. Nights are dandy and all, and yeah one would normally go to a bar at night, but i'm the kind of person who likes to sit for a drink.

Enter: 4th of July weekend, a sunny day at the park, and a desire for an afternoon beer. I sat and drank for about 5 hours with a friend--a couple beers and a couple cocktails. We had a good time talking to the bartenders, all of whom knew what they were doing behind the bar. They were attentive and responsive, friendly, and patient.

I bless the fact that the bar now has windows. It would have been depressing had we been in that dank cave it used to be.
author: Phuong M.

description:
Try the hefferveisen on tap, it is as refreshing as a freshly mowed lawen, perfect summer weather drinking.

This place is a much needed addition to the neighborhood.  I hope it inspires a couple more establishments to pop up or improve.
author: Sean H.

description: Drinks here were great and they also had a great beer selection. The place gets pretty crowded, so be ready to wait for your drinks a bit, but it wasn't too bad. Good location, good atmosphere and will definitely be coming back!
author: George M.

description: Solid neighborhood spot with a good beer selection and a full bar.  Happy hour till 7pm. Had to minus 1-star since they allow people to bring in their dogs.
author: Dilly M.

description:
The Churchill has a fun and funky vibe.  However, I don't wait to get into bars.  Unfortunately, that tends to be the case at this establishment.  

You can get a great classic cocktail or one of their own concoctions.  I had the bees knees which was lemony with a bit of honey, but not too sweet.  Mine came in a chipped glass which made the drink less than perfect.  

You can only run a tab if you plan on spending more that $20. 

 It is very loud which competes with look of the place.  I would rather a quieter bar with the same look.
author: Megan P.

description: Thursdays are great too. Same great music, great crowd.  One note: a lot of the drinks sound sweet but aren't overly so (which I'm a HUGE fan of), and if you tell them things you like, they'll concoct something epic for you (like a cross between a dark and stormy and a mojito that I can't wait to go back for). (Halloween Monday was fun too). A great place to meet up before your evening as it's accessible by car, muni, it's centrally located and it's easy to get a cab.
author: Mike V.

description:
stumbled on this place by chance after dinner at a restaurant nearby and so happy i did.

cool ship-style decor, very nice bartender who struck up a conversation about my stay in san fran and even recommended a few bars around the area. eventually, he had me try the "cape daquiri." considering i had been planning a few trips to a few cocktail bars around the city, i was very impressed with this one. simple and flavorful. i wish i had known about this place sooner during my trip. plus, as many reviewers have mentioned, the drinks are awesomely served in mason jars.

i can't wait till i go back to san francisco to go back to this bar and try some more neat house cocktails.
author: N. M.

description:
the design of this place makes me want to weep. it's so perfect.

there are nostalgic edison lights, everywhere, making for a dimly lit bar. there are industrial-like tables, and in the area with squishy couches has tables with upcycled wood from old wine barrels. there are pool tables, and the only color the bar has is a huge american flag on the wall (ugh so perfect), and the bathroom is so chic (i judge a place by how well their bathroom is decorated).

the ambiance is sexy and everyone is hip. they serve drinks in mason jars. i want to live here. oh yeah, they allow dogs here... there was one giving everyone high fives and kisses, just like your drunk aunt at your last family reunion, but less hairy and cuter.

i like coming to this bar every time i come to SF, because it's really sexy. anywhere that serves its alcoholic beverages in mason jars should receive 6 stars.
author: Ava M.

description:
I've now stopped in here twice for a single drink each time...  and I'm not sure exactly how to rate it as it still feels a little pre-pubescent and needs some more time to bake.

Atmosphere:  Pleasantly dim and muted colors... about what can be expected of any "hip" new business...  The look is beginning to feel a bit overplayed but it's done pretty well here.  A decent amount of seating, but could use more considering the low-energy vibe.  They have a pretty fancy looking pool table for those who partake.

Crowd:  A strange mix... quite a few of the BOC hangers-on in addition to some Haight/Mission with a little Marina thrown in.  It will be interesting to see where it settles out.

Drinks:  This is what's keeping Churchill from 4 stars.  A quick look at the booze racks behind the bar will tell you that they have just about every cocktail ingredient at their disposal, but the cocktail menu is very limited and doesn't inspire one to be adventurous.

(Bonus points for the simple fact that it's not the BOC... though if they somehow brought back the dirty awesome Transfer I would personally give butt birth to 5 stars to give them.)
author: Kevin F.

description:
Used to hang her with my boys back in the day and on a recent visit to hook up with Carlos and James to relive the old days we decided to drop in here? WTF happened? this bar is beautiful. the inside is soo cool and clean. Nary a smell of poppers in the air anymore. Girls bathroom, a real girls bathroom.
The crowd is very interesting. where do they come from. its sure a mix. young hipsters queens sprinkled about and some well dressed gentleman. No one segment seemed to dominate yet they all coexisted in harmony. love love love this place. Of course they have mixologist and although i stuck to Scotch most of the night i did try a whiskey cocktail (the name escapes me) which was killer.
author: Cathy M.

description:
Lovin' this brand spankin' new bar!

I used to live right around the corner from this place and remember it being this diiirty, tacky bar that I always passed by but never gave a 2nd thought about. And now... look at it! LOOK! This dingy spot has transformed into a bar w/ a rustic ambiance & quite the classy sheen to it. The sleek wood paneled exterior and nautical rope accents are both done up nice, making this a bar that I just can't help but be drawn to. It all kinda reminded me of Bloodhound, but less woodsmen/hunter-themed, more American history-themed (obviously w/ a name like "Churchill!).

The lemonade-like Homefront cocktail was definitely the hit of the night. I love my drinks on the rocks and this one was a winner. The bartender who was slingin' drinks my way was super friendly and accommodating- especially when I asked him a question or 2 about the cocktail selection. Very cool.

There's a pool table in the back and decent seating here, but man was this place packed to the gills! And like many others have mentioned, this place is LOUD. I somehow "succeeded" at catching up w/ 3 good friends, but it's highly likely that I misheard half of what they said. 

Expect to be surrounded by boysboys and more boys since Churchill is located on the cusp of the Castro. Great place to hit up if you're looking to go to Blackbird up the street as well. Same kinda vibe & scene.

What a refreshing facelift to the Duboce Triangle point!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
On our way to the Pride/MJ Flash mob, we stopped by for a quick drink before we put on our dancing shoes and party hats on. Please note that Churchill is not a quick drink type of place. Churchill is a great catch-up, lets converse, and drink our cocktails slowly type of place. When I say drink slowly I mean...those cocktails were on strong side and tossing it back was not an option. LOL We were in here for less than 15 minutes, but I was impressed by the improvement in decor (remember when it was BOC...eeek!) and we loved the variety of drinks options. 

Quick rundown of the two drinks we ordered: 
Bees Knees - Tastes like HARSH honey drank. (Will not order again)
Predu? - Tart...gin...Not a bad starter drink.

What I found kind of interesting about Churchill --- the ability to order beers at different sizes. Pretty cool for someone trying to watch their beer portion sizes.
author: Lisa T.

description:
So I went here  on Saturday and from what I can remember, the "Bees Knees" was awesome. For some reason it reminded me of the Gimlet I had at Zam Zam in the Haight. I had one other drink that was served in a jar. Didn't think too much of that. They also got Hangar 1 vodka, so next time I must ask  the bartender too mix up something with the Chipotle Vodka. I love the music they played. Having a refreshing drink,  getting a great buzz while listening to Arcade Fire with an attractive person on my port and starboard side.
Just FYI, there is a minimum 20 buck charge for a tab. Some dude tried to get away with five and he did which goes to show how cool and understanding the bartenders are in the place. So all in all good times. The menu isn't as extensive as Rickhouse, but the close proximity makes up for that. Recommended.
author: Marvin O.

description: Woody and very packed on weekend nights. A good beer selection, some kind of intense stout on tap for fellow Guiness lovers. Clean restroom and very dim lighting. I would try to start sober so you can enjoy the ambiance.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
This place rules. Trevor made me an amazing 'American Trilogy' and a 'Remember the Maine' (being a Mainer, I have a soft spot for this drink). Trevor's a master at what he does; efficient, focused and super talented. 

In sum, reasons why I'm obsessed with this place:
- Trevor is the man (as are the other mixologists)
- I'm obsessed with WWII
- Great interior
- Central location
- Not a "scene" 

All in all a great spot. Congrats on a successful opening and best of luck!
author: Charlie H.

description:
I'm so thankful Churchhill came to this corner. When it was the transfer it just looked so gross inside...and what was the bar after that? ell, who cares.

Anyway, finally, I have tried Churchhill a few times. I have to say, the beer selection catches my eye! Also, I can't help but notice how big this bar really is. Why didn't the previous places make it this nice? 

I was here for the Superbowl, and let me tell you, it was awesome. The energy of the area and the vibes inside the bar were enough to make me be interested in the Superbowl. 

Well, once I get over the beers on draught, I will be trying a cocktail.
author: Alexia R.

description:
New bars always take time to settle into a neighborhood. Rebel is still going through that process. Churchill is targeting a decidedly Blackbird crowd, following several years of non-Blackbirders at this location. The space, upgraded with new couches and lounge chairs, is still awkward at best. The large open space near the door needs a bust of Churchill or a Union Jack to create energy there. The seating proved ill-advised for our party to communicate easily.

On the plus side, the windows let in evening light to break open what was a cavernous, seedy space, though I suspect this venue will be more of a night spot. The flickering lamps provide a warm glow beckoning to passersby on the 22-Fillmore or J-Church. The beer menu is excellent: the San Leandro-based Drake's dry stout is worth the $4 at happy hour.

The crowd was mixed, with quite a few groups of ladies on the official opening night. The three of us moved on to Blackbird for some $4 whiskey sours.
author: Randy M.

description: The drinks were awesome and the service and bar were immaculate! My friends and I were very impressed. An excellent happy hour spot that I'll definitely visit again if I find myself in San Fran again.
author: Sateria R.

description: Came here with two of my college girls who moved up to The Bay after we graduated. YAY! First impression- hipster. HAHA...but of course that's expected.  The beers are served in mason jars- cute, but for cocktails and other liquors one can have the appropriate glass.  There weren't many people there the day we went- quite possibly because it was in the afternoon.  We were just there to kill some time before dinner.  There's a pool table in the back- at times it was a little hard to shoot because the stick was hitting the walls, tables, chairs nearby.  It's not very spacious,  Overall, I enjoyed my afternoon there because it wasn't crowded and noisy.  It was just a good place to chill.  (dont take my word if youre going for evenings or later)  :0]
author: Selina C.

description: It's always noticeably dim in this bar, but its easier to operate under the cover of darkness anyway. Haven't had a disappointing drink there yet and it attracts good people. PLUS It's dog friendly - sometimes, a bulldog named Winston hangs out there. Perfect, right?
author: Isabelle W.

description: Went here a couple weeks ago on a Friday night after going to see an Improv show in the area. It was a perfect place to pop in to get a fun drink before the bars all closed up. It was pretty crowded and loud in there but there was still a spot to sit down and just sit and enjoy a drink if you want by a window. I even noticed a pool table in the back. The drinks were really good too. I tried the El Diablo with reposado tequila, creme de cassis, lime juice, ginger beer and this rum drink that was super intriguing with coconut, lime juice & rootbeer! Both were delicious. I would definitely come back.
author: Megan Z.

description:
It finally happened ...

Hipsters Invade The Castro

This "Pottery Barn-meets-Hipsterville" bar sits on a skanky corner across SAFEWAY, and they think the "decor" justifies the expensive drinks and attitude??

NO THANKS!  ...attitude from the bartender made it loud & clear he didn't want my kind there.

To the short whiteboy bartender:  HEY..when someone orders a drink and specifies, "with a splash of soda"..that implies that the SPLASH is to be floated on top. You don't STIR a damn drink when a splash of soda is requested.  Go back to bartender school in Spokane, and learn how to make REAL drinks, not hipster ones.

The concrete floor has a dangerous "trip & fall" hazard:  a hole the size of a soccer ball in the center of the floor. Yeah, great ..just what you need in a place that serves booze.

If I want to have a cocktail at Pottery Barn MINUS the attitudinal hipsters, I'll sneak a can of PBR into the real Pottery Barn up the street, and have a better time.
author: Ted K.

description: Overall great bar. Good drinks, reasonably priced. Fun ambiance with a decent crowd, but not too packed.
author: John L.

description: Liked it. Thumbs up. Anthony is the coolest bartender.
author: Kenson K.

description: Great location at Church and Market. Cool booth couchy seating and high top tables. Full liquor and average beer selection. Mixed crowd on Castro, Haight, Duboce, Dolores neighborhoods intersection. Nice ramp to the bathroom. Safeway across the street for late night chicken.
author: Brian L.

description: I was just lounging at DP with the homies and decided to go for one drink with my girl. We took the J Church down towards Market and landed at this spot. What awesomeness randomness can bring! This spot is a great space! There are sofas and coffe table style seating areas as well as bar table tops with bar stool seating! Drinks are cheap and well made! TVs for sports viewing definitely a plus! Pool table in the back! Nice large windows to really get a naturally lit ambiance!!! Coming here again with out of town visitors!
author: Claire D.

description: Pretty cool bar. They have really good cucumber gimlets!
author: Rochelle I.

description: Came here the Saturday before Halloween.  It was really chill - able to sit back looking at the people dressed up. If I could sum this place this up it would just be that it's chill - which is what I like.
author: Christine B.

description: I was having a strong love affair with Churchill- but we might be breaking up. I don't think I can frequent a bar where when a half full cocktail is spilled down my pants looking as if i pissed myself without so much as an apology or offer of a new drink from the bartender. Her response was topped with a heavy dose of an attitude to boot. Those menus are heavy and who knows whose fault it was when the bill passed from the bartender's hands to mine. I get it. The place is busy and the cocktails are a multi-part process. Somewhere in sf-people like the edge of being too cool for school and the aloofness of some mixologists. But this local appreciates good service with her 10 dollar cocktail. And isn't going to settle for less.
author: Kate B.

description:
This bar is seriously nothing special. In fact, I hate it. The crowd is consistently obnoxious. The bartenders are all like Moose from Archie comics, except small in stature. 

It was only my second time here, and will have been my last. I ask for a Fernet neat and the bartender looks highly confused, "you mean a shot of fernet?" I meant fernet in a glass, because good bartenders don't measure their drinks by shots, but I say "sure." It is $7, a rip-off. I have to use the atm because their minimum for cards is $20. After the atm fees and $1 tip I essentially pay $13 dollars for 1 "shot" of fernet. Should have gotten a mini like I usually do.
author: hailey k.

description: Had a beer here on a Thursday evening and was a good low key vibe. Little later is when the crowd starts to come in and it can get packed. All in all, a good place for a drink and some billiards.
author: Paul G.

description: My friend brought me here after she had a great time. It definitely had a nice atmosphere and a wide selection of drinks but unfortunately, I wasn't impressed. My drink was 'meh' and our bartender was inattentive and seemed careless; more interested in making small talk with his coworker. If I return, it will be for a quick/convenient beer and hopefully, with different bartenders.
author: Kendall K.

description:
First time in this new-ish local bar.  As Larry David might (annoyingly - so forgive me) say... Pretty, Pretty Good!  I like the decor and atmosphere.  Very urban chic.  So of course it brings out all the little urban chics!  By that I mean the place was packed full of cuties last night.

I did think that if a bomb went off there the West Coast supply of Urban Hipsters would have been seriously interrupted ( and the resulting glut of skinny jeans would clog the market for years) - thankfully that didn't happen.

The crowd seemed to be mixed straight and gay (which is always nice to see).  There are lots of seats but never quite enough for the press of folks crowding in.

As for drinks - I guess cocktails are always expensive (and exotic whisky and/or whiskey cocktails more so?) but the service at the bar was prompt, pleasant and expert.  I was offered a couple of tasters of some American whiskeys before making my choice - now THAT is a rarity these days and I liked it. (I ended up drinking a Rye from Idaho!)  The selection was great tho - of both whiskeys and whisky (the latter being Scotch).  My friends were on cocktails - one was a tea-whiskey daiquiri - sounds revolting but was actually pretty good!

So I like the place and - like Sonja S advised in her review - you should check out all the lamps!  Not a curly florescent nor cold LED in sight. All steampunk retro (but really - don't let that put you off) and it matches the rest of the raw materials decor.

Go get drunk and flirt.
author: Stephen M.

description:
I like this Bar, I  do.   I've been here two times.  Once on a Friday evening and once on a Sunday afternoon.   Both times were nice, but damn does it get loud in there.

Drinks are good.  I think i always order the Homefront, which I like.  Good beer selection, and good Bloody Mary's too.   Bartenders were pretty friendly depite being busy as well.

I also like the mix of people.  I think there were more staight people than gay, but it was mixed which is nice.

I'll be back.
author: Courtney C.

description:
This place is not that bad to start out your night.  Came here for a friend's birthday on a Friday night and it was pretty packed inside.  The only problem was that they don't seem to have ventilation in the place and it was hot inside.  On the plus side, the place seems to have good energy and friendly people.  They have a pool table and small lounge area toward the back of the building.  Also, the spacious and clean restrooms were a plus compared to most SF bars I've been to.

Okay, as for the bar itself, the service is a little slow.  I don't know whether to blame the bartenders or the patrons who order drinks that require 22 ingredients and the bartender to do a lot drinking shaking.  I just want a drink and mine only has 2, yes, 2 ingredients.  It's like you are sobering up at the bar as you wait to order another.  After writing this passage, I think I'll blame the patrons for making the bartenders slow this night (not sure if it's like this on other nights).  Drink prices seem reasonable - Stoli was $6 which is not bad for an SF bar.

Overall, it's a fun place with nice people and randomly selected songs playing and I would come back.
author: Paul C.

description: Was only here for a short amount of time before venturing off to the next bar for the night, but the experience wasn't too bad. Our bartender was quick and attentive. Mid 20's-early 30's crowd from what I saw. A lot of guys, I felt like we were the only girls in that joint. Overall, not too bad experience. Maybe next time we'll stay a little longer :)
author: Samantha H.

description:
Alright, so perhaps I'm a little biased, but I still believe that the best incarnation of this particular location was the Transfer.  A gritty, grimy bar with amazing music and cheap drinks.  How I miss the pool tables with boards placed over them that would allow me to dance until the wee hours of the morning.  But this isn't a review for the Transfer, now is it?

I like Churchill.  I like the rustic atmosphere and the unique cocktail selections, and I like seeing a little more of a mixed crowd in my bar.  I went with a friend to check it out, and it was a busy Saturday night, but the bartenders were quick and attentive.  I got a nice vibe from the place, and I definitely will have to come back for a happy hour very soon.

The only thing that bothered me was that an one of their long tables was reserved at 9:00 PM and was only indicated to be so via a small sign at the far end of the table, which of course we didn't see. My friend and I had only just sat down and were asked to move.  I don't like the idea of reserving tables at a bar for some reason...maybe it's me.  But overall, I really like this bar and will be back soon.
author: Tim F.

description: Awesome interior and seating, good cocktails, and a lady that was handing out bite sized doughnuts....need I go on?
author: Bryce C.

description: Love this bar. The ambiance makes you feel like you're in a LES/NYC bar....except with an abundance of bros. Still awesome anyways.
author: Alicia B.

description: Used to be my old 'hood bar, now I still return (across town) for the delicious IPAs and fancy mixed drinks. Fun atmosphere, and a pool table to boot!
author: Jane F.

description: This place is too crowded, too douche-y and too hipster late at night, but they make good drinks and they have 4505 Chicharrones for sale!  I prefer the next-door neighbor, Blackbird, but this is a good place to go early in the night before it gets too crowded.
author: Sally L.

description: After passing by Churchill a few hundred times last summer I finally made it in last friday night. The bar is very cool inside, and if you're lucky enough to get a table (which we were) it's a good spot to drink a few drinks. I didn't try any of the cocktails, but I would be willing to go back to do so.
author: Eliza D.

description:
My partner and our friends were at this new bar called Churchill by Church Street and 14th Street last Saturday, second  night after they opened on Friday, June 3rd.  

It would have had potential if the bartenders will tone down their ATTITUDE!  Specially the FAT guy with the ponytail!  What's up with the attitude dude?
author: Jay I.

description: Really good drinks and nice decor. Great place to come for happy hour.
author: Conor B.

description: Great house drinks. True SF vibe. I've gone here for happy hour and work events. The owner(s?) are super supportive and willing to work with you on creating some thematic drink specials. Makes for a fun after-work environment! (Tons of seating too which is usually a rarity!)
author: liz c.

description:
I had to meet a guy about a horse here.

Seems weird to me that I had never been before but I know I will be coming back.

First blush - I love the bar. In general I am a bit OCD so that orderly set-up was outstanding. 
Next - great stools. Maybe I have just sat my behind on too many, but I respect a comfortable seat.

Dig the interior with the walls, wood ceiling, and the rope overhang just giving this place a more unique feel to it. I really wish I could have snagged one of the leather chairs to give it a sample. They looked comfy.

They served me up a nice whiskey (or two) and what more can a guy ask for? Friendly bartender perhaps? Luckily they have that too. This is definitely the type of place I want to go for a drink and it is nice enough that I probably wouldn't embarrass myself by staying to get drunk. I can hit one of my regular dives for that!
author: Nick B.

description: I think it was appropriate that I had a date rife with mixed signals at Churchill.  Yes, I will say it.  Churchill seems to be a little too San Francisco.  I really have no idea what sort of crowd will be here.  Are those two hipsters having some beer in mason jars or is that a first date between two Mission gays?  Are those lesbians out for a drink because they were able to get a babysitter or are those two sisters?  It's not that I feel uncomfortable, I just feel unable to define my surroundings.  I suppose this is how all bars should be: a meeting grounds for all slices of life.  And as for Mr. Mixed Signals, he gave the same treatment to a friend of mine literally three days later.  Talk about small world.  Talk about a creep.
author: Jeremy G.

description: If you like classic rock and good drinks this is a place to visit. You'll see all sorts of people in this bar and I've noticed it can get pretty crowded on Saturdays. It's a good place to hang out with friends. It can get loud so it's hard to have a conversation here, I've left with a sore throat. Cons: one of bartender who always seem to be in a bad mood. Pros: variety of people, drinks, music.
author: Natalia Q.

description:
I stopped by here for the second time recently. I really wanted to like the place but I left with an only so-so taste in my mouth.
Nice that they take credit cards (Why the hell are most SF bars cash only??)
NOT nice that they have a $20 minimum when using one. Oy. 
The one guy bartender was fast and efficient, but when I went up to get another drink the younger bartender ignored me, as I stood there for like 10 minutes, then when some tall chick came up way after me, he took her order. WTF?? I f'in HATE that sh*t-- learn how to frickin' scan the room and see who came FIRST. Grrr. So I went to the other end of the bar and had the gal bartender make my drink. I have bartended and I am well aware that it is important to (even when making drinks) address someone who walks up and is waiting to place an order. It's called multitasking and (hint hint- gets you better tips because people notice good service!!)
She was not apparently capable of this, BUT she was courteous and fast once she took my order, and I appreciate the fact that she didn't IGNORE me. Drinks are pretty good- they just need to do some training for the workers in being aware/multitasking.
author: Tom T.

description: So, like everyone, I hate MUNI.  I take the N Judah, which frequently breaks down, most recently at the Duboce & Church stop. Abandoned, I decided to walk down to Market Street, and stumbled into this gem. It's on the corner, with huge windows overlooking Market Street, and great interior design.
